utility_right_navs.title: Follow AMA Journal of Ethics on Twitter

current_issue.description: People suffering some form of violence routinely seek health care. As first responders, clinicians are required to treat these patients equitably and promote their best interests. In clinical practice, guidelines can help or hinder clinicians’ capacities to fulfill these duties to patients who are victims of gun violence or rape, for example. Standards of care regarding sexual assault protocols and forensic examinations have important limitations that need clinical and ethical consideration.

title.text: What If a Resident or Medical Student Is Raped? Hospitals’ and Academic Medical Centers’ Title IX Obligations
How Should Physicians Make Decisions about Mandatory Reporting When a Patient Might Become Violent?
Clinicians’ Need for an Ecological Approach to Violence Reduction
How Should Physicians Make Decisions about Mandatory Reporting When a Patient Might Become Violent?

featured_case.citation: AMA Journal of Ethics. November 2017, Volume 19, Number 11: 1132-1138.

title.text: The AMA Code of Medical Ethics’ Opinions on Physicians’ Financial Interests
The Affordable Care Act and Insurer Business Practices

polls.question: A child’s parents ask you for advice on whether to enroll their 5-year-old in a phase 3 clinical trial for an agent that might reduce the size of the child’s brain tumor. You’ve heard about this trial in a medical news source recently, and you suspect that the promising results of the phase 2 trials seemed sensationalized. You consider referring the parents to your colleague specialist, but worry that this particular colleague might overemphasize potential benefits and underemphasize potential risks. What will you do?

label.text: Suggest that the parents read the medical science news report about phase 2 results of the trial so that they can cultivate some hope and be more informed about this option after getting such a devastating diagnosis for their child.
Investigate the trial details on your own and invite the family to come to your office for at least an initial conversation.
Admit that you don’t know enough about this trial to advise them well and refer your patient and her family to the specialist.

Ask an administrative staff member from your office to set up a collaborative family meeting with the specialist so that you can also attend and participate in the discussion and in advising the parents.

about.title: About the Journal
about.description: Our editorial mission is to help medical students and physicians make sound ethical decisions in service to patients and society. Founded in 1999, the AMA Journal of Ethics explores the ethical issues and challenges that students, residents, and other physicians are likely to confront in their training and daily practice.

themes.title: Global Reproductive Health Ethics in the 21st Century
Ethical Considerations in Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery
Religion and Spirituality in Health Care Practice
Ethics, Policy, and the Roles of Physicians in Care of the Dying

paragraph.text: Our Discussion Forum provides an opportunity for students, educators, and clinicians to engage experts in an online conversation about important ethical issues in health care.
The AMA Journal of Ethics invites original submissions for peer review on the following themes that will be explored in upcoming issues.
We invite medical students, resident physicians, and fellows to apply to serve as theme issue editors.
Never miss an issue again, sign up for our newsletters to be alerted each time we publish a new issue.
